title: 105_s341
content: The Act titled "National Bipartisan Commission on the Future of Medicare Act of 1997" establishes a commission known as the National Bipartisan Commission on the Future of Medicare. The Congress acknowledges the importance of the Medicare program in providing healthcare coverage to senior citizens and individuals with disabilities. It is noted that the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund is facing financial challenges, with projections of insolvency by 2001 due to spending exceeding revenue since 1995. The aging population and declining number of workers contributing to the program further exacerbate the fund's solvency issues. The trustees of the Medicare program's trust funds have highlighted the growth in spending within the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund. The Medicare program's Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund is unsustainable, requiring urgent action to restore financial integrity and uphold the nation's commitment to senior citizens and individuals with disabilities. SEC. 4. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is tasked with reviewing the financial condition of the Medicare program, identifying problems threatening the Federal Trust Funds, analyzing potential solutions, and making recommendations to restore solvency through 2030. The Commission is responsible for reviewing the financial condition of the Medicare program, identifying issues affecting the Federal Trust Funds, and proposing solutions to ensure solvency until 2030. Recommendations include establishing the financial structure, balance of benefits, implementation timelines, and analyzing other relevant matters. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 15 members appointed by the President, Senate Majority Leader, and Speaker of the House. The Comptroller General will advise on methodology, and members will serve for the duration of the Commission. The Commission, consisting of 15 members appointed by various officials, will be headquartered in the District of Columbia and will meet as called by the Chairperson. Ten members constitute a quorum, with the Speaker of the House designating the Chairperson. Vacancies will be filled promptly, and members will not receive additional compensation for their service. Each member will receive travel expenses. Each member of the Commission will receive travel expenses and per diem in lieu of subsistence according to federal regulations. SEC. 6. STAFF AND SUPPORT SERVICES. The Chairperson appoints an executive director of the Commission who is paid at the rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. The executive director can appoint staff with Commission approval, without following certain Civil Service Laws. The executive director can also procure temporary services with Commission approval. The executive director can procure temporary and intermittent services under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission. The Commission has access to resources and information from various government branches. The General Services Administration will provide suitable office space for the Commission's headquarters. The Commission's headquarters will be equipped with all necessary facilities for its proper functioning. The Commission has the power to conduct hearings, accept gifts, and use the United States mails. They must submit a report to the President and Congress within 1 year and terminate 30 days after submitting the report. SEC. 10. FUNDING. The Commission is authorized to receive necessary funds from the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund to carry out the purposes of this Act.
